sub_topic: Finding the maximum flow in a network.
message_1:
Consider a network of pipes connecting a source S to a sink T, with four intermediary nodes A, B, C, and D, as shown in the diagram below. The edges represent the capacity of the pipes. What is the maximum flow that can be sent from S to T?

![image.png](attachment:image.png)

Capacity:

S-A: 16
S-B: 13
A-C: 12
B-D: 12
C-T: 20
D-T: 14
A-B: 10
C-D: 9
message_2:
To find the maximum flow that can be sent from S to T, we can use the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm. We will find augmenting paths and update the residual capacities until no more augmenting paths can be found.

1. Initial flow: 0
   Augmenting path: S -> A -> C -> T
   Bottleneck capacity: min(16, 12, 20) = 12
   Update capacities:
   S-A: 4
   A-C: 0
   C-T: 8
   A-B: 10
   S-B: 13
   B-D: 12
   C-D: 9
   D-T: 14

2. Flow: 12
   Augmenting path: S -> B -> D -> T
   Bottleneck capacity: min(13, 12, 14) = 12
   Update capacities:
   S-A: 4
   A-C: 0
   C-T: 8
   A-B: 10
   S-B: 1
   B-D: 0
   C-D: 9
   D-T: 2

3. Flow: 24
   Augmenting path: S -> A -> B -> D -> T
   Bottleneck capacity: min(4, 10, 2) = 2
   Update capacities:
   S-A: 2
   A-C: 0
   C-T: 8
   A-B: 8
   S-B: 1
   B-D: 0
   C-D: 9
   D-T: 0

4. Flow: 26
   Augmenting path: S -> B -> A -> C -> D -> T
   Bottleneck capacity: min(1, 8, 9, 9) = 1
   Update capacities:
   S-A: 2
   A-C: 1
   C-T: 8
   A-B: 7
   S-B: 0
   B-D: 0
   C-D: 8
   D-T: 0

No more augmenting paths can be found. The maximum flow from S to T is 26.
